question:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, increased pigmented hair over the chin and upper lip, and purple stretch marks on the abdomen. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:
Na+ 154 mEq/L
K+ 2.8 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L
HCO3- 30 mEq/L
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Glucose 236 mg/dL
ACTH 2 pg/mL (N = 7–50)
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?"
prompt:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of difficulty sleeping and fatigue. Menses occur at irregular 35- to 50-day intervals and last 3–7 days. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. She has had an unintentional 10-kg (22-lb) weight gain over this period. She also reports decreased sexual desire and increased hair growth on her face and arms. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows central obesity, increased pigmented hair over the chin and upper lip, and purple stretch marks on the abdomen. She has a prominent hump of fat over the base of the dorsum of her neck and decreased proximal muscle tone and strength. Serum studies show:
Na+ 154 mEq/L
K+ 2.8 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L
HCO3- 30 mEq/L
Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL
Glucose 236 mg/dL
ACTH 2 pg/mL (N = 7–50)
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?"A)Adrenalectomy
B)Polychemotherapy and radiation therapy
C)Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy
D)Partial nephrectomy
output0: Adrenalectomy is the most appropriate treatment for this patient because she has a classic presentation of Cushing's syndrome. Her symptoms of central obesity, purple stretch marks, and increased hair growth on the face and arms are consistent with this diagnosis. Additionally, her laboratory results show elevated levels of cortisol and ACTH, which further support the diagnosis. Adrenalectomy is the most effective treatment for Cushing's syndrome and can help to resolve the patient's symptoms and improve her quality of life.
output1: Polychemotherapy and radiation therapy are the most appropriate treatments for this patient because she has a classic presentation of Cushing's syndrome, a hormonal disorder caused by excessive production of cortisol. The patient's symptoms, such as weight gain, central obesity, purple stretch marks, and decreased muscle tone, are all consistent with Cushing's syndrome. The laboratory results also support this diagnosis, as the patient's serum cortisol levels are elevated and her ACTH levels are suppressed.
output2: Transsphenoidal hypophysectomy is the most appropriate treatment for this patient because she has symptoms of Cushing's disease, which is caused by an overproduction of cortisol. This surgical procedure involves removing the pituitary tumor that is causing the excess cortisol production.
output3: The patient's symptoms and laboratory results are consistent with Cushing's syndrome, a disorder caused by excessive production of cortisol. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is partial nephrectomy, which is the surgical removal of the affected adrenal gland. This procedure is the most effective treatment for Cushing's syndrome caused by an adrenal adenoma, which is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome.

question: maple syrup urine disease because of the following amino acids that can not be metabolized, resulting in α-keto acids accumulate in the blood?
prompt:
maple syrup urine disease because of the following amino acids that can not be metabolized, resulting in α-keto acids accumulate in the blood?A)leucine
B)alanine
C)glycine
D)histidine
output0: Leucine is one of the amino acids that cannot be metabolized in Maple Syrup Urine Disease, which is a rare genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to break down certain amino acids. As a result, leucine accumulates in the blood and causes the characteristic symptoms of the disease.
output1: Alanine is one of the amino acids that cannot be metabolized in Maple Syrup Urine Disease, resulting in the accumulation of α-keto acids in the blood.
output2: Glycine is one of the amino acids that can not be metabolized in Maple Syrup Urine Disease, resulting in the accumulation of α-keto acids in the blood.
output3: Histidine is one of the amino acids that cannot be metabolized in Maple Syrup Urine Disease, leading to the accumulation of α-keto acids in the blood.

question: First local drug-delivering system drug is:
prompt:
First local drug-delivering system drug is:A)Tetracycline.
B)Minocycline.
C)Doxycycline.
D)Metronidazole.
output0: Tetracycline is the first local drug-delivering system drug. It was developed in the 1960s and was used to treat a variety of conditions, including acne and rosacea.
output1: Minocycline is a drug that is commonly used to treat acne and other skin conditions. It is also the first local drug-delivering system drug to be approved by the FDA.
output2: Doxycycline is a local drug-delivering system drug that is commonly used to treat a variety of conditions, including acne and rosacea. It is applied topically to the skin and works by reducing inflammation and killing bacteria that cause infections.
output3: Metronidazole is a drug commonly used to treat infections caused by anaerobic bacteria, such as Bacteroides fragilis, which is a common pathogen in the gastrointestinal tract. It is also used to treat other infections, such as pelvic inflammatory disease and abscesses.

question: Translocation seen in Ewing's sarcoma is:
prompt:
Translocation seen in Ewing's sarcoma is:A)t(8,11)
B)t(11,22)
C)t(11,18)
D)t(14,18)
output0: The translocation seen in Ewing's sarcoma is t(8,11), which is a genetic abnormality that leads to the production of a chimeric protein that promotes tumor growth.
output1: The correct answer is B)t(11,22), which is the most common translocation seen in Ewing's sarcoma. This translocation results in the fusion of the EWS gene on chromosome 11 with the FLI1 gene on chromosome 22, leading to the development of this type of cancer.
output2: The translocation seen in Ewing's sarcoma is t(11,18), which is a specific genetic abnormality that occurs in this type of cancer. This translocation results in the fusion of two genes, leading to the development of Ewing's sarcoma.
output3: The correct answer is D)t(14,18). This is a translocation that is commonly seen in Ewing's sarcoma, a type of bone cancer. The translocation results in the fusion of the EWS and FLI1 genes, leading to the development of the disease.

question: A patient has bilateral conductive deafness, tinnitus with positive family history. The diagnosis is -
prompt:
A patient has bilateral conductive deafness, tinnitus with positive family history. The diagnosis is -A)Otospongiosis
B)Tympanosclerosis
C)Meniere's disease
D)B/L otitis media
output0: Otospongiosis is a condition characterized by the presence of otosclerosis in both ears, which can cause conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. The positive family history also increases the likelihood of this diagnosis.
output1: Tympanosclerosis is a condition in which the eardrum becomes hardened and thickened, which can cause conductive hearing loss. The patient's bilateral conductive deafness, tinnitus, and positive family history all point to this diagnosis.
output2: Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can cause vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss, and it is often associated with a positive family history. The other options, otospongiosis, tympanosclerosis, and B/L otitis media, are not associated with a positive family history.
output3: Bilateral conductive deafness, tinnitus, and a positive family history are all symptoms of B/L otitis media. Otospongiosis and Tympanosclerosis are both conditions that can cause conductive hearing loss, but they are not typically associated with tinnitus or a positive family history. Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can cause vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss, but it is not typically associated with conductive hearing loss.

question: A diabetic patient having sensory involvement, tingling, numbness, ankle swelling, no pain. Diagnosis is
prompt:
A diabetic patient having sensory involvement, tingling, numbness, ankle swelling, no pain. Diagnosis isA)Charcots joint
B)Gout
C)Rheumatoid ahritis
D)Ankylosing spondylitis
output0: The symptoms of sensory involvement, tingling, numbness, ankle swelling, and the absence of pain are consistent with Charcot joint, a condition that affects the joints and is often associated with diabetes. Gout, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis are not typically associated with these specific symptoms.
output1: The symptoms you described, such as sensory involvement, tingling, numbness, ankle swelling, and the absence of pain, are consistent with gout. Gout is a type of arthritis that can cause sudden and severe joint pain, particularly in the big toe. The patient's symptoms suggest that they may have developed gout in their joint.
output2: The symptoms described - sensory involvement, tingling, numbness, ankle swelling, and no pain - are consistent with rheumatoid arthritis. Additionally, the patient's diagnosis is not Charcot's joint, gout, or ankylosing spondylitis.
output3: Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that affects the spine and other joints. It can cause sensory involvement, tingling, numbness, and swelling in the affected areas. The patient's symptoms of ankle swelling and sensory involvement are consistent with this diagnosis.

question: 60-year-old woman, insulin-dependent diabetic, presenting right shoulder pain of nocturnal predominance of several weeks of evolution. It does not refer traumatism. Physical examination highlights an active and passive limitation of all shoulder movement arcs. What clinical picture do you suspect as the first diagnostic possibility?
correct_answer: A septic arthritis of the shoulder.
options: A)A malignant tumor located in the proximal epiphysis of the humerus.
B)A septic arthritis of the shoulder.
prompt:
60-year-old woman, insulin-dependent diabetic, presenting right shoulder pain of nocturnal predominance of several weeks of evolution. It does not refer traumatism. Physical examination highlights an active and passive limitation of all shoulder movement arcs. What clinical picture do you suspect as the first diagnostic possibility?A)A malignant tumor located in the proximal epiphysis of the humerus.
B)A septic arthritis of the shoulder.
C)Adhesive capsulitis
D)An acromioclavicular osteoarthritic degenerative process.
output0: The clinical picture of a 60-year-old woman with nocturnal shoulder pain of several weeks of evolution, without trauma, and with limited movement in all shoulder arcs, is consistent with a malignant tumor located in the proximal epiphysis of the humerus. This is the first diagnostic possibility.
output1: The clinical picture described in the case, with nocturnal predominance of shoulder pain of several weeks of evolution, active and passive limitation of all shoulder movement arcs, and no history of traumatism, is consistent with a septic arthritis of the shoulder. This is the first diagnostic possibility.
output2: The clinical picture of a 60-year-old woman with nocturnal shoulder pain of several weeks of evolution, limited shoulder movement, and no history of trauma, is consistent with adhesive capsulitis. This is a common condition in older adults and is characterized by inflammation and scarring of the capsule surrounding the shoulder joint, leading to pain and limited mobility.
output3: The clinical picture of a 60-year-old woman with right shoulder pain of nocturnal predominance and limited movement, without any traumatic history, is consistent with an acromioclavicular osteoarthritic degenerative process. This condition is more common in older adults and is characterized by pain and limited mobility in the shoulder joint.

question: Which of the following will increase the production of free radicals (free radical) it?
prompt:
Which of the following will increase the production of free radicals (free radical) it?A)觸酶（catalase）
B)Oxidizing enzyme (oxidase)
C)Superoxide dismutase (superoxide dismutase)
D)Bran amine sulfur peroxidase (glutathione peroxidase)
output0: Catalase is an enzyme that is responsible for breaking down hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. When hydrogen peroxide is present in the body, it can react with other molecules and form free radicals, which are highly reactive molecules that can damage cells. By breaking down hydrogen peroxide, catalase reduces the amount of free radicals in the body, thereby preventing cellular damage.
output1: Oxidizing enzymes are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of electrons from one molecule to another, resulting in the formation of free radicals. Therefore, the presence of oxidizing enzymes will increase the production of free radicals.
output2: Superoxide dismutase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of superoxide anions into hydrogen peroxide and oxygen. This process increases the production of free radicals, which can be harmful to the body.
output3: Bran amine sulfur peroxidase (glutathione peroxidase) increases the production of free radicals. This enzyme is responsible for catalyzing the oxidation of glutathione to glutathione disulfide, which leads to the formation of free radicals.

question: A study investigating the use of adalimumab for the relief of peripheral arthropathy in patients with psoriatic arthritis was conducted. The study utilizes a crossover design in which half of the study participants are given adalimumab for a month while the other half takes placebo. After a 2 week washout period in which no one takes any adalimumab, the group that was originally on adalimumab is given placebo for a month while the group that was originally taking placebo is given adalimumab for a month. Pain in all affected joints is assessed clinically by follow-up visits every two weeks for the duration of the study. Which of the following is true about cross-over study designs?
options: A)Crossover studies avoid the ethical issue of not giving all participants access to a novel therapeutic agent
B)Crossover studies minimize the effects of differences between participants
C)The purpose of the washout period is to increase the length of the study to gather more data
prompt:
A study investigating the use of adalimumab for the relief of peripheral arthropathy in patients with psoriatic arthritis was conducted. The study utilizes a crossover design in which half of the study participants are given adalimumab for a month while the other half takes placebo. After a 2 week washout period in which no one takes any adalimumab, the group that was originally on adalimumab is given placebo for a month while the group that was originally taking placebo is given adalimumab for a month. Pain in all affected joints is assessed clinically by follow-up visits every two weeks for the duration of the study. Which of the following is true about cross-over study designs?A)Crossover studies avoid the ethical issue of not giving all participants access to a novel therapeutic agent
B)Crossover studies minimize the effects of differences between participants
C)The purpose of the washout period is to increase the length of the study to gather more data
D)1 and 2
output0: Crossover studies avoid the ethical issue of not giving all participants access to a novel therapeutic agent because all participants receive both the experimental and control treatments. This ensures that all participants have access to the novel therapeutic agent, which is a key ethical consideration in clinical research.
output1: Crossover studies minimize the effects of differences between participants because each participant is exposed to both the treatment and placebo conditions. This allows researchers to control for individual differences between participants and isolate the effects of the treatment.
output2: The purpose of the washout period in a crossover study is to allow participants to wash out of the treatment they were previously receiving and to give both groups an equal chance to experience the placebo effect. This is done to minimize the effects of differences between participants.
output3: Crossover study designs avoid the ethical issue of not giving all participants access to a novel therapeutic agent, because all participants receive both the experimental and placebo treatments. This design also minimizes the effects of differences between participants, because each participant serves as their own control. The washout period is included to ensure that any effects of the previous treatment are eliminated before the next treatment is given.

question: Question linked to the image nº28 40-year-old man who consulted for blurred vision, pain and right red eye of 3 days of evolution. Biomicroscopic exploration is shown in the image. The intraocular pressure in that eye is 10 mmHg. The fundus does not show alterations. What is the first diagnostic option?
prompt:
Question linked to the image nº28 40-year-old man who consulted for blurred vision, pain and right red eye of 3 days of evolution. Biomicroscopic exploration is shown in the image. The intraocular pressure in that eye is 10 mmHg. The fundus does not show alterations. What is the first diagnostic option?A)Chorioretinitis
B)Keratitis herpetiformis
C)Anterior uveitis.
D)Glaucomatocyclic crisis.
output0: Chorioretinitis is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms of pain and blurred vision, as well as the fundus examination showing no alterations. The intraocular pressure of 10 mmHg is within the normal range and does not support the diagnosis of glaucoma.
output1: The patient's symptoms of blurred vision, pain, and red eye, along with the biomicroscopic examination showing a herpetic keratitis, suggest that the first diagnostic option is Keratitis herpetiformis. The fundus examination not showing any alterations and the intraocular pressure being within normal limits also support this diagnosis.
output2: The patient's symptoms of blurred vision, pain and red eye, along with the biomicroscopic exploration, suggest anterior uveitis as the first diagnostic option. The absence of fundus alterations and the normal intraocular pressure also support this diagnosis.
output3: The patient's symptoms of blurred vision, pain, and red eye, along with the intraocular pressure of 10 mmHg, suggest a diagnosis of glaucomatocyclic crisis. This is a type of acute angle-closure glaucoma that is more common in older adults. The fundus examination does not show any alterations, which supports this diagnosis.
